discourse_list.title: [Signal Request] Reset delegation metrics for Hasu

content.content: Request Recognized delegates are currently scored on voting frequently and communicating their reasoning. Right now, the scores consider the lifetime performance of each delegate. This has the benefit that delegates who scored well in the past can afford to take a couple weeks per year off w/o falling below the threshold. But it has the downside that delegates who have a bad score today can never “redeem themselves” and reach a good score again. In my case, I haven’t been interested in working as a salaried delegate intially but rather use the delegate position as an activist platform for improving governance and treasury management (examples here and here). However, this work has been more time consuming than I expected and I cannot in good conscience continue w/o any compensation. The easiest path is to also become a salaried delegate, vote only on the matters where I have expertise (such as governance and treasury management), and abstain for the rest. However, with the scores I have accumulated to date I could score perfectly for years and still never qualify for payment. So this model of measuring delegate performance is clearly broken. As a hotfix, I propose resetting my score once. I originally wanted to propose to allow all delegates to reset their scores once per year, but after deliberating with @GovAlpha-Core-Unit, it seems that a generalized rule for delegates would have to pass via MIP whereas a one-time-change can pass via signal request. This request is orthogonal to any more fundamental discussions we’re having about how to incentivize delegates going forward.  Pros and cons Pros:  Hasu’s delegation score would accurately reflect the new commitment, not historic performance Compensation only begins if performance meets MIP61 standards going forward Retain one of the larger MKR delegates  Cons:  Would lead to an increase in DAI expenses for the protocol It becomes harder for prospective delegators to see Hasu’s true voting history Can lead to other delegates requesting a reset before a MIP is formalized   Poll    Reset delegation metrics for Hasu?  Yes, reset delegation metrics for Hasu No, don’t reset delegation metrics for Hasu Abstain     0 voters      Next steps This Signal will run for ~2 weeks, ending on July 23th. If more than 50% of the non-abstaining votes are in favor it will proceed to a governance poll to settle the issue. If Yes does not get a majority in this signal, no Governance action will be taken as a result.

content.content: Thanks Prose. This context is necessary to evaluate this SR proposal. The charitable solution seems simple.   Withdraw this SR (It will not pass).   Wait for the full govalpha delegate proposal to come to the table and be debated.   At that time add a provision allowing for retroactive compensation evaluation starting from a date (let’s say Aug 1.)   Wait for MIP to be ratified.   Once ratified, if a delegate has complied and would have been eligible under the past window, they can apply for payment as per the MIP.    This path achieves 3 things:   Allows for a charitable consideration of Hasu’s circumstance, but applies the same terms even evenhandedly to all delegates.   Places the burden of performance on delegates prior to compensation. This is important in instances of historic underperformance.   It ensures integrity of the MIP system and governance. This path will lead to thorough discussion and evaluation of compensation terms, including retroactive comp. It also ensures engagement with the various issues by all parties (a more robust proposal upon ratification).

content.content: prose11:  You could have proposed one though, and I think it’s fair to mention the retroactive Compensation Signal GovAlpha helped put together on your behalf when we changed the comp formula the first time. This is just to say that we have used signals to correct imbalances with the Delegate Comp MIP before so any comparisons to other instances of non-action should keep this in mind.   Sure I could have proposed something but we already see what the reception is here to someone proposing money for themselves. @PaperImperium proposal for retroactive comp for example. I believe this conceptually sets a bad precedent and the optics are bad for those who will gain to put forward the signal. @aburban90 for example has worked tirelessly for years without any retroactive comp, I know there are many others. Some proposed and got their own retroactive comp @Risk-Core-Unit for example I am not even sure if Vasu got a piece of that (I hope he did). Rather than broaden this discussion further I will narrow it down somewhat. In the case of delegates or any other situation it is my preference is that instead of people coming forward to ask for money for themselves, GovAlpha being somewhat neutral here could reach out with more global proposals based on comments by any DAO participant and include in any proposal for change, who such a change will affect how so that (1) the ramifications of such a proposal to the entire DAO could be assessed (i.e. who will it affect how, and how much the retroactive change will cost). In this case I suspect any change would affect me, @PaperImperium @Hasu I am not sure who else nor for how much. My main point is that changes need to come NOT from the people who will get such compensation, but from a 3rd party who does not gain from such measures being considered or passed. In the case above any change to delegate, performance resets, or changes to delegate compensation could affect all delegates. When these things come forward as Global system changes, from a party that doesn’t gain (GovAlpha), with a list of who they will affect how and the cost involved (if possible to project) this then imho puts forward a neutral proposal where we know ‘what will be changed’, ‘how it will affect the group’, ‘whom it will affect specifically’, ‘and what it will cost’ vs. a party that stands to gain and is in fact ‘conflicted’ in terms of interest. This way when the compensation change comes through we probably won’t need a second proposal to pass governance, and can move straight from proposal being adopted with compensation changes going straight to an executive. The above kind of model then makes a DAO with neutral stewards looking out for other people’s interests vs. a DAO of selfish individuals looking to ‘get something for themselves’. Generally I am for change in this regard as long as the change is system wide, applied universally to those it applies to vs. this specific 1off MakerMan, PaperImperium or Hasu, etc. needs a special disposition. I honestly cringed when my own 1-off came up and I think I abstained from voting on that poll, I can’t speak for Paper but suspect him putting up that request was also awkward, can’t speak for Hasu but I can say neither Paper or myself threatened to ‘quit’ over such things and to me is disappointing but not unreasonable to expect to hear. The fact delegates get compensated in DAI and don’t get MKR vesting is disappointing so they are treated differently than all CUs/contractors. If this changes will it also be done retroactively and across the board to all affected. Time will tell. @prose11 I have always appreciated GovAlpha looking at these things from a larger perspective and appreciate a MIP being in the works here to correct the situation. If MakerDAO is going to seriously consider this then I respectfully request @PaperImperium and myself be added as well and a general look at who this might affect. If Hasu is in some desperate need for DAI compensation perhaps we can pass a signal request for a compensation loan against future income.
